I know! I had the intuition that it might be from a race condition between the different builds (assuming that the 4 sub-build use the same mysql db). 

Do you know for a fact whether it's the case or if each sub-build gets its own db?

I've never used the BashOperator to run an airflow command but I guess that's fair game. Typically we think of `clear` and `backfill` commands as manually triggered. Also note that `airflow backfill` will parallelize.

One good news is that in an upcoming branch the scheduler will actually fill in holes. So if you go back and clear sections of a DAG for previous date it will actually pick up the slack.

The `SequentialExecutor` probably shouldn't be used beyond tutorial and early playing around. I wrote it for testing purposes and to allow early bootstrapping while using sqlite. Setup a mysql/postgres and graduate to the local executor!

I'm not sure I was perfectly explicit: I can unfortunately only run one of the daily or range tasks at a time. This is why we were using a `SequentialExecutor` at first.

Your remark got me thinking though. Actually, I only want the daily and range tasks to run one at a time, but I'd like to have any number of external task sensors running/waiting at the same time. This sounds like I could use a `LocalExecutor` with one pool for the daily and range tasks with max parallelism of one, and one pool for the external task sensors with unlimited parallelism.

Unfortunately, I see that the BackfillJob class doesn't look at those pools either => Would it make sense to add something similar to the `SchedulerJob.prioritize_queued` method to the `BackfillJob` class or was it omitted on purpose ?
How much data is that? Xcoms should only be used for metadata only. It gets serialized into a field in the metadata database.

65535 bytes. I am storing only metadata - passing an array of items to process for the next operator.
For the one that works, the data size is 21272 bytes. How large is big enough? Is 65Kb a large enough value to fail? @mistercrunch

No, I am not absolutely sure certainly not with the docker instances they now use. I would be very surprised if it is shared though. Besides, it only happens with the python 3.4 builds not with the python 2.7 and I think that is suspicious.

I'll see if I can track something down, but in this area of Airflow I don't know my way around as easy. And, firstly, I will see if I can fix the caching because something is still off there.

It does definitely look like a race condition. I purged the caches and all builds finished, next build failed partially again. It also happens with py27 btw. If you restart the failed job it works. Im not sure where/why it happens. I will open an issue with the travis guys, see if they can help.
- I've fixed the caching now build times actually decrease ;-).

Small update: the python environments (3.4 - 2.7) share the same cache. So instead of 4 there are just 2. Don't know if this can be the cause as tox separates environments. It might point to the issue that mysql might be shared (although I still doubt this)

I have a similar use-case.  I do it like this:
- Use `LocalExecutor` (to avoid a 'wait' task from blocking everything)
- separate into 2 DAGs (daily vs. the range)
- For the daily tasks, set `depends_on_past: True`.  Even if it's not entirely true
- Have my "range" task wait on the last period of the daily task using an ExternalTaskSensor

`depends_on_past: True` may not be literally true for your job, but it provides two behaviors as a consequence.  1) The daily jobs execute one at a time, 2) when the final task of your "range" executes you know that all previous tasks are done.

Yes backfill doesn't play nice with pools currently. It'll get fixed soon.

Thanks @mlimotte - I hadn't thought of that and I think it will indeed do the trick !

@mistercrunch : Probably, what I really want is to have an extended set_downstream with relative dates (similarly to the ExternalTaskSensor or the depends_on_past). I want to be able to say "This task depends on the run of this task for this date". The dependency would be explicit (which is not the case with sensors). Would this feature make sense ? If it's the case, I'd be happy to implement the backend.

Looks like BLOB type in MySQL limits to 65KB
https://philihp.com/blog/2011/maximum-sizes-of-mysql-blob-fields/

For now you can probably just ALTER TABLE and set that value column to MEDIUMBLOB or LONGBLOB. 

MEDIUMBLOB seems like a better default for Airflow, though I'm unclear on whether SqlAlchemy will allow a cross platform way to set this.

ExternalTaskSensor allows to implement "This task depends on the run of this task for this date" where "this date" is relative to the current date :
http://pythonhosted.org/airflow/code.html#airflow.operators.ExternalTaskSensor

Build failures are unrelated, the test_external_task_sensor succeeded, so I'm mergin.

Thanks for the fix!

I changed a setting in travis to reduce parallelism to see if it helped, but I've still seen errors after that. I may just go back to a SequentialExecutor in master and see if it fixes it. We can fix this race condition or issue with LocalExecutor in a branch. 

Maybe cgroups kill extra processes? I'll try a SequentialExecutor with parallelism.
Might work, but as you get a dedicated 2 cpus and 4GB per build I'm not expecting that the groups are the issue. It might solve the issue for now.

What I'm trying to say is that `ExternalTaskSensor`s don't create explicit dependencies : they are not directly accounted for in `TaskInstance.are_dependencies_met`. Hence I need to introduce ad-hoc solutions to my problem, either by spawning many `ExternalTaskSensor` that are continuously waiting or by introducing fake `depends_on_past` as proposed by @mlimotte.

I'm imagining an extended `set_downstream` that would allow me to express "This task depends on the run of this task (same DAG) for this date" as **an explicit dependency** rather than through adhoc solutions. Would this extended `set_downstream` make sense in airflow or is it something definitely out of scope because it doesn't fit airflow's paradigm? 

Thanks for your quick replies!

It's a documented functionality that's not very intuitive. `start_date` is only used to seed the task, once task is seeded by the scheduler or say a backfill command, the scheduler just moved on.

It'd be fair game to alter the scheduler to not kick tasks off that haven't reached their start date.

Ah now I understand what you meant by parallel. I thought you mentioned the build parallelism.

I've ran into similar issue with 1.5.2 and was able to resolve by adding the `--ship_dag` switch on the CLI.
I've also seen the same error when AIRFLOW_HOME environment variable hasn't been set.

The functionality described by Thoralf above boils down to the ability to define a DAG with operators depending on several previous executions of operators within the same DAG. For example, a daily trend batch (1) and a trend diff batch (2) that processes the results of (1) over the last 7 days. In that example, (2) should be scheduled for the first time only after 7 days of results of (1) are available.

At the moment, an operator can only declare an upstream dependency towards another operator with identical execution date (via `set_upstream()` ), or towards itself with execution date being the latest previously scheduled (via `depends_on_past=True`). 

Airflow also allows to build the operator (2) with a start_date explicitly set to 7 days after the start_that of (1), but this seems to be a concern leaking from the Airflow scheduler to the developer designing the DAG: ideally Airflow would resolve that start_date by itself. Also, this start_date does not enforce that the execution of (2) will happen after all the required executions of (1) are finished. 

It seems that `ExternalTaskSensor` (with several DAGs) cannot be used for that purpose either because it has no direct influence on the scheduling but rather allows the corresponding task(s) to be launched and kept waiting. In the example above, that would yield 7 instances of task (2) in case of a `LocalExecutor` or `CeleriExecutor`, or even just one of them at a time in case of a `SequencialExecutor` until one of them blocks forever, which would halt the whole task sequence. 

Our suggested resolution would be a PR along he following lines: 
- in `DAG`, add an `execution_calendar` object which relies on `utils.date_range` and `self.schedule_interval` to provide the execution dates to be scheduled (among others, required in `BackfillJob`) as well as the past execution dates. + adapt `BackfillJob` and others accordingly.
- in `DAG` and `BaseOperator`, adapt the `set_dependency`, `set_downstream` and others to allow to declare a number of past upstream executions (defaulting to 1), possibly with new `DownstreamDependency` and `UpstreamDependency` classes. We would not declare if those past executions need to be successful or not, since this concern is already captured by `task.trigger_rule`.
- in `TaskInstance.are_dependencies_met()`, adapt the SQLAlchemy query to rely on the DAG `execution_calendar` as well as on the number of past upstream executions of each upstream dependency to query the status of depended upon tasks.

I will have a intern in my team from January onwards, who is will be implementing a predictor of when jobs will actually finish (ie. giving an eta to a DAG and maybe their individual tasks). This will help in capacity planning. If he has enough time he might also cast a stone at creating a Optimizer Scheduler, ie one that based on the time DAGs take schedules them to make the most use of resources available.

Part 1 would already be quite nice I guess, part 2 icing on cake. Any thoughts?

A few notes: 
- `start_date` is necessary for the scheduler to know where to start. Also for change management as you introduce new tasks to a DAG, it's an important piece of metadata that the scheduler can't guess
- `start_date` also informs `depends_on_past` to not be applied on that first date

It does make sense to add more functionality to the dependency engine, and time ranges is reasonable. There's already a fairly complex flow for understanding "why isn't my task getting triggered" and I want to make sure that we keep or increase the level of clarity around that as we make the engine more flexible.

I think "Trigger Rules" might become the place to store rules more complex than "this task depends on this task". In its most complex form, you could have arbitrarily complex rules that could be combined in complex ways. Picture something like `trigger_rules=(DependOnPast(self) and FullDagExecution('some_other_dag')) or AllHellBreaksLoose()`. 

In the meantime it's pretty easy to write custom sensors, what about an alternative to `ExternalTaskSensor` that can take date ranges as input and be start_date aware?

Thanks for your answer !

Indeed, we see where you coming from for the start_date, thanks for clarifying.

We're happy to see that you're also interested in more functionalities such as the time ranges.

We totally agree with the need for clarity. We were actually thinking about adding some justification to the task state that could be displayed in the UI. Maybe those justifications would contain reasons for success, failure or still queued, etc.

On the main topic : If we understand correctly, you'd like to gather the concepts of upstream / downstream dependencies, depends_on_past and trigger rules (aka all_success, any_failure, etc) into a flexible grammar. This grammar would allow to parametrize upstreams dependencies with time ranges and expected status (success, failure, etc) and to compose them with logical operators.

Here's a link to an overview of a suggested refactoring of the API which includes all those concerns as well as the task runnable state and justification that could be displayed in the UI. We're aware of the importance of API backwards compatibility, more thoughts will probably have to be thrown in there to address it.

https://gist.github.com/thoralf-gutierrez/00555b2a667099cfcfcb

To add some more context we are developing data analytics solutions on Spark and we are looking for something very similar to Airflow. We would definitely prefer to contribute the necessary effort to make it more flexible instead of developing a new in-house solution!

If you're available, we'd be happy to have a chat with you to discuss the topic and how we could collaborate on it! (see my email on my github profile)

How many tasks has the DAG? Also note that the tree view has trouble when the shape of the DAG converges and expands, exploding the number of paths while computing the tree view. 

A workaround is to filter on the graph view and pivot into the tree view.

Long term fix would be to change the d3/javascript to receive a graph data structure instead of a tree data structure and be more dynamic. I don't think that will be on top of the priority list very soon...

Nice. The proposal captures key elements.

We need a base class that can be extended to define new triggers. Evaluate would receive the context (as operators execute method does). Maybe overloading or/and would be nice but that can be tricky.

Then you can extend this base class and create anything from `AllSuccessTriggerRule` (receives a list of task_ids) to `DependOnPastTriggerRule`, to  `LocalWeatherIsGoodEnoughTriggerRule`. Generally I prefer a wide collection of TriggerRules that are more targeted (`TaskDateRangeTriggerRule`) over a few with a complex list of parameters.

We'll have to preserve the previous API somehow.

I've also been thinking about a feature in the UI that would break down why a task isn't getting triggered, having this more modular framework would make it easy to show the list of rules and their current status.
Thanks!

Ok I have been digging a bit further. The main issue seems to be that the configuration is imported in the local scope of each module (ie. from configuration import conf) and thus configuration items cannot be changed after the import. A better way is to do an "import configuration".

I'll see if I can get example working and then work my way through it.

See also: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/6268278/modifying-global-variables-in-python-unittest-framework

Bad approach, bail. Turns out all that code was there for good reasons :) 

Restarted here: https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/597/files

Well you cannot assign a new object in place of `airflow.configuration.conf` since the different module will be referencing the old object `id`, but you can alter the content of the object. I just tested that `conf.read('altered_airflow.cfg')` does adapt when the next `conf.get` is called. 

Then the only thing is to make sure that no conf.get calls are cached at the module level, we need to make sure that `conf.get` is only called in routines, not in module scope.

We usually run a backfill on a single schedule to test/debug. You may (or may not) want point your `AIRFLOW_CONFIG` env var to an alternate airflow.cfg file. It for you to define how you want to insulate your tests and prod environments

Yeah I've seen a few lingering locks here and there.  The first thing is to make sure you don't have any airflow related processes running. You can also kill blocking processes in the DB. I'm not sure if you could just go and drop the db either or if the lock would prevent that as well.

Sweet!

Initdb and resetdb themselves works fine after the killing the initial sets of process that hanged. 

Each Gunicorn worker thread that I add to the server seems to create another process in the database that locks the metadata table(or attempt to). I suspect Gunicorn is the cult-pit of this. 6 gunicorn thread = 6 processes to kill. 

On a side note, the lock also prevents dropping the db. I can kill the blocking processes in the DB tho.
I've seen the disk i/o error msg when using a LocalExecutor against a Sqlite database. Sqlite doesn't support concurrency so it fails when multiple processes try access the one db file.

I did a little bit of hacking at things on my end and looking at the alembic documentation: http://alembic.readthedocs.org/en/latest/branches.html

If we modify the alembic.ini file in airflow such that it looks for migrations in the airflow root and AIRFLOW_HOME. I'm not sure if this is the right syntax for an alembic.ini file (in my testing, I hard coded AIRFLOW_HOME) but it should be something roughly like:

``` ini
version_locations = %(here)s/migrations %(AIRFLOW_HOME)s/migrations
```

and modify utils.upgradedb so the last line is:

``` python
command.upgrade(config, 'heads') # note the s in heads
```

This should let people set up a migrations/versions folder in their airflow home and branch the metadata db.
